column4: You should be able to get to the grub menu by holding shift during boot.
I can get the grub menu, thats not an issue
Ahh, I misunderstood your initial comment in the channel. Just so you know, the automatic timeout was disabled *because* it was detected that Ubuntu wasn't booting successfully.
Have you tried booting an older kernel?
ahh ok that makes more sense, but i'm still stuck :P
yep, same thing
fail at (initramfs)
What is the output of "cat /proc/partitions" from the initramfs shell?
I'll be back in 5 minutes with an answer :)
Hey i'm back Jordan_U
it gave me a table, no errors, do you want me to type out the table?

Just the last column, and a picture works as well. Basically I'm wondering if your root filesystem's partition is being detected at all. The next step would be to try to mount it from the initramfs shell.
sda
oops
sda, sda1, sda2, sda3, sda4, sda5
!helpme | orugaman
thats the last column
Do you know off hand which of those would be your root filesystem?
er, uh, no.  I believe windows and windows recovery are the first to though
From a LiveCD, could you run boot info script as explained here: http://ubuntuforums.org/showthread.php?t=1291280 and pastebin the RESULTS.txt?
ok i can try that, but its getting late here.  hopefully you will be on tommorow?
I don't know.
